labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

labels.name: needs-wg-input
labels.description: Issue needs to be presented and discussed in the WG

issues.title: Carl's review comments
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
* [x] Is the title of the draft too general? Given the installation focus, using generic "measured components" name seems a bit broad.

> Note: scope has been expanded to address #2 

* [x] Adding a few words about native and tunnel would be good

* [x] In the Component Version row in Table 1, it may be worth including a reference to https://semver.org/
* [x] Do we need an explicit "component type" field (e.g., code, config)? As long as "component name" provides a clue for what to do with these fields then maybe "component type" is unneeded. That could be clarified
* [x] How would one know what to do with the signer and countersigners fields?

> Note: I transplanted the relevant portions of Simon's email to clarify this aspect

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: @carl-wallace, thanks for your review.  I think I have addressed all your comments in the [editor's copy](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-fft-rats-eat-measured-component/draft-fft-rats-eat-measured-component.html).

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Hearing no pushback I am going to close this.  @carl-wallace, if you think otherwise, please reopen the issue.

issues.title: Digest value definition
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
I don't think the digest value should be restricted to things in memory or to start up time.

Seems like this could be used for RTIC (Run Time Integrity Check) which is something that can get run before every transaction or such.

Also, you might want to measure parts of the file system, registers or other.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Good point.

I am not against expanding applicability.  That said, the one concern I have is whether `tstr` is sufficient to carry *all* possible component identifiers.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I'm personally OK with tstr for the name. Keep it simple until there's a reason to do more.

Mostly, I'm interested in rewording so that it can be used for RTIC and other than the traditional measured boot.

issues.title: Make signer optional
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body: It is completely OK to rely on EAT's signing mechanism to authenticate the measurements.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: I think I misunderstood ckt. It's not about signing the measurement. It's about authorizing install, right? Probably should call it something very different and describe that in a big way. Still might want it optional. A bit confused...

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> I think I misunderstood ckt. It's not about signing the measurement. It's about authorizing install, right?

Yes, exactly.

Semantically, it is equivalent to Open-DICE's [Authority Data](https://pigweed.googlesource.com/open-dice/+/refs/heads/main/docs/specification.md#input-values), i.e., a thumbprint of the verified boot trusted authority.

> Probably should call it something very different and describe that in a big way.

Makes sense.  Do you have any suggestions for the naming?

> Still might want it optional.

+1

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: You're trying to name some company or person (a legal entity), right? How about what EAT OEM ID did? EAT OEM ID is just trying to name a legal entity.  You could add CKT, or CKT could one way to make a random ID.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
And call it "installing entity" or such rather than signer.

I guess you've thought about it, but your adding another legal entity into the mix here in addition to SW manufacturer, HW manufacturer... Is that what you want to do?  Seems like you'd want to know the SW manufacturer of the component just as much as who installed it.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> You're trying to name some company or person (a legal entity), right? How about what EAT OEM ID did? EAT OEM ID is just trying to name a legal entity. You could add CKT, or CKT could one way to make a random ID.

In PSA the Signer ID represents the identity of the signer of the firmware component's manifest.  So, yes, it is _"some company or person"_, which in PSA's secure boot model is reduced to the thumbprint of a public key.

I am happy to extend the type to include other applicable types, i.e.:
```
signers: [ + signer-type ]

signer-type /= ckt
signer-type /= TODO
```
and I like the idea of reusing something already specified, but my reading of EAT is that the semantics of `oemid` are limited to HW manufacturing entities.  What we need here is an OEM ID for software entities :-)

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
So I'm thinking of this a bit generally outside of TCG and PSA stuff. That's right, isn't it? There's no requirement that it be used in those contexts, right?  If so, the signer/installer gets interpreted in a variety of contexts.

It's not very clear to me what signer/installer is. If the end user installs an app, are they the installer? If the component is the chip HW fuse block area, is the device OEM the installer? Who's the installer if you're measuring part of the file system.

I assume the installer is distinct from the manufacturer of what is being measured because you're not calling it SW_manufacturer. 

Maybe you can say more about how the sender should create the signer/installer and what the receiver should do when it gets it.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> So I'm thinking of this a bit generally outside of TCG and PSA stuff. That's right, isn't it? There's no requirement that it be used in those contexts, right? If so, the signer/installer gets interpreted in a variety of contexts.

(In the future) we want to use this as a replacement for PSA software measurements, so we'd like to be able to losslessly map our current semantics onto it.
But yes, we also want this to be generally useful, otherwise we wouldn't have started this :-)
One easy (and reasonable) thing is to make signer(s) optional, so if you don't need it you can just forget it even exists.  This would cover the RTIC and file system object use cases, as well as non-signed software components.
Another is to allow signer(s) to have different types.
First, though, we need to agree on the high-level semantics of the field.
It seems to me the most natural mapping is to "code signing", where the code signer can be identified via an X.509 cert, a raw public key or a thumbprint thereof, a COSE Key, etc.
Would that work for you?

> I assume the installer is distinct from the manufacturer of what is being measured 

In general, yes.
 
> Maybe you can say more about how the sender should create the signer/installer and what the receiver should do when it gets it.

Sure, that shouldn't be too hard.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: @laurencelundblade thanks for the discussion so far.  After giving it some more thought, I have made some tentative changes to address your comments.  In a nutshell: [signers are now optional](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-fft-rats-eat-measured-component/draft-fft-rats-eat-measured-component.html#name-measured-component-informat) (i.e., your initial point), and any specific encoding requirements are [on the EAT profile](https://thomas-fossati.github.io/draft-fft-rats-eat-measured-component/draft-fft-rats-eat-measured-component.html#section-4.1.2) that uses measured components.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I'd like to see some text explaining that the EAT signature will often be the way measurements are protected and authenticated. I think this is a major use case for measured components. It is an efficient way to secure measurements.

CoSWIDs can be unsigned, so we're already doing that in EAT measurements, but it is not discussed. The discussion of [signed/unsigned manifests](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-eat-25.html#name-manifests-software-manifest) in EAT is an example of what should have been there for measurements.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Closing this as Laurence's original point (i.e., to make signers optional) has been addressed.  The discussion on clarifying what the semantics for `signers` is has moved to #6

issues.title: Signing seems underspecified
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
ckt is just a key ID, right? If you want signing, you need to bring in COSE like CoSWID does.

Also seems like a bit of a challenge to all support JOSE / JWS.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Closing this based on https://github.com/thomas-fossati/draft-fft-rats-eat-measured-component/issues/3#issuecomment-2021416501

issues.title: Add security and privacy considerations
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Component ID (name and version):
  * could give an attacker insight (S)
  * could reveal private information (P)

The requirement on the component's name stability potentially enables correlation (P).

issues.title: How do signers work?
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
There is a signer field and a section on signers mentioning UEFI, X.509 and such, but there is no mention of any signing scheme or format. If there is to be a non-EAT signature on some measured components there has to be a signing data structure.

You can put signed CoSWIDs in EAT, so there is one way to have independently signed measurements, but the point of measured components is to not use CoSWID, right?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> There is a signer field and a section on signers mentioning UEFI, X.509 and such, but there is no mention of any signing scheme or format. If there is to be a non-EAT signature on some measured components there has to be a signing data structure.

There are two separate signatures:

1. On the *installed* component.  This is made by a vetted supply chain entity and verified during secure boot by the relevant cryptographic RoT - e.g., the key hierarchy rooted in the ROTPK (Arm's TBBR), or PK (UEFI).
1. On the *measured* component.  This is made by the RTR that signs the (EAT) evidence - e.g., the IAK (Arm PSA), or CPAK (Arm CCA).

From the point of view of the latter, the specific signing scheme and format used by the former are irrelevant.  The only important thing is to be able to somehow track the identity of the (installed component's) "signer" and report it to the verifier.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
OK. It's making some sense again, but it is probably impossible to understand from the current text and/or without a large amount of context about UEFI or such. If this is to be interpreted in the UEFI context, then the text should probably say that in a strong way and provide the necessary references and such.

Let me ask this way.  When Qualcomm designed the Brew app download system, we required each app be signed by the vendor/developer of the app. For example, we would require that Byte Dance sign the TikTok app. But then, Qualcomm who ran the App Store, would sign it again to indicate the developer and app had been vetted and was OK to run on commercial phones. The phone only checked for the second signature. The first signature was for protection and authentication while the app was being developed and approved. I think the "signer" here is like the Qualcomm signature. It's the entity that approves running on the device. It's not the vendor of the component. Is that right?

(Also, my knowledge of UEFI is limited...)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> OK. It's making some sense again, but it is probably impossible to understand from the current text and/or without a large amount of context about UEFI or such. If this is to be interpreted in the UEFI context, then the text should probably say that in a strong way and provide the necessary references and such.

UEFI's secure boot is certainly a motivating use case (and so is Arm's TBBR), but the concept is more generic than those specific instances.  In fact, your Brew example is yet another possibility, like any other "code signing" scheme.
 
> Let me ask this way. When Qualcomm designed the Brew app download system, we required each app be signed by the vendor/developer of the app. For example, we would require that Byte Dance sign the TikTok app. But then, Qualcomm who ran the App Store, would sign it again to indicate the developer and app had been vetted and was OK to run on commercial phones. The phone only checked for the second signature. The first signature was for protection and authentication while the app was being developed and approved. I think the "signer" here is like the Qualcomm signature. It's the entity that approves running on the device. It's not the vendor of the component. Is that right?

It is right.  However, if the original developer's signature was not removed (and could also be measured during boot), it could, in principle, be added to the `signers` array alongside Qualcomm's.
 
> (Also, my knowledge of UEFI is limited...)

Whoever claims complete knowledge of UEFI is a liar :-)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: What kind of explanatory text would you like to see in the "Signer" section?

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I'll never tell a lie about UEFI. Other things...

Something like this for the text?

> The signer field identifies the entity that gave permission to install and/or run the component.  An example of this is the signer of secure boot components in UEFI or other secured boot schemes. It may also be the controlling entity in an app store. Typically the permission mechanism is by a signature that is evaluated by the boot ROM, OS or app launcher so the field is named "signer".
> 
> It is never the identity of the manufacturer of the component such as you would find in a manifest like a payload CoSWID.

This begs the question about what name space the signer comes from and how the recipient of a measured component knows what to do with the signer field. Maybe you just say that this is out of scope.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> I'll never tell a lie about UEFI. Other things...
> 
> Something like this for the text?
> 
> > The signer field identifies the entity that gave permission to install and/or run the component.  An example of this is the signer of secure boot components in UEFI or other secured boot schemes. It may also be the controlling entity in an app store. Typically the permission mechanism is by a signature that is evaluated by the boot ROM, OS or app launcher so the field is named "signer".
> > It is never the identity of the manufacturer of the component such as you would find in a manifest like a payload CoSWID.
> 
> This begs the question about what name space the signer comes from and how the recipient of a measured component knows what to do with the signer field. Maybe you just say that this is out of scope.

Thansk @laurencelundblade .  I'll fit your proposed text in.

issues.title: Can EAT profiles extend a measured component?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: Can EAT profiles extend a measured component?  Or is it immutable?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Noting that _some_ profile-specific behaviour is already possible around the ["signers"](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-rats-eat-measured-component-00.html#section-4.1.2-2) attribute.

Issue #12 tries to carve out a general purpose (albeit minimal) profile-specific extension space.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Addressed in #12

issues.title: Filesystem Object
issues.author: hannestschofenig
issues.body:
Is the use of a file system object a use case we want to support? If so, we need to be more precise of how this works. 

E.g. COSWID supports file system item but do we want to reuse the concept from there?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
I don't think measured components should replicate CoSWID functionality.

The `file-entry` and `directory-entry` structures defined in [Section 2.9.2 of RFC9393](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9393.html#section-2.9.2) are way too complex - i.e., they have too much cruft attached, and are recursive in nature.

Conceptually, what we need to borrow from CoSWID is something like `fs-name`, but fully qualified, as a component name.

For example:
```
[
  / id / [
    / name / "/etc/service.conf"
  ],
  / measurement / [
    / alg / "sha-256",
    / val / h'3996003d486fb91ffb056f7d03f2b2992b215b31dbe7af4b37
              3431fc7d319da3'
  ]
]
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
@hannestschofenig what should we do with this?

Do you want to add text that explains how the `name` could be used to identify a file system object, as in my comment above?

issues.title: JSON tunnelling is superfluous
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Carsten comment:

> Thomas: You tried to justify base64url-encoding data into CBOR with “escaping complications”.
> There is no escaping in CBOR.
> I would say that any CBOR format that carries around base64url-encoded byte strings is deeply confused.
> Just carry around the byte string.

issues.title: add (optional) SVNs to the mix?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
There are specific use cases where the measurement includes a Security Version Number (SVN). 

(For context, the SVN is an anti-rollback counter utilized in certain attestation schemes, such as Intel TDX and AMD SEV-SNP.)

There was a brief discussion in the context of EAT (see [EAT#111](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/eat/issues/111)), but it was ultimately not pursued. 
One reason it may have been dropped is that its "natural" scope relates more to the measured component (i.e., a portion of the overall TCB) rather than a global level (the entire TCB). This makes it less suitable as a separate claim.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: This is probably worth WG discussion.

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: It's always valuable to receive feedback from the group. If the hash is included, there should theoretically be no need to report additional information. However, it seems to be done regardless. This makes it difficult to completely ignore. In my opinion, offering it as an optional feature doesn't hurt.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
If we want to add it, we have a few options:

* as an alternative to digest:

```
(digest / svn)
```

* Both digest and SVN are possible, even one alongside the other:

```
non-empty<(?digest, ?svn)>
```

* Digest is mandatory and possibly complemented by SVN:

```
(digest, ?svn)
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: I am closing this issue due to the group's lack of interest.

issues.title: Measurement extensions for CoRIM?
issues.author: deeglaze
issues.body:
I'm trying to wrap my head around how we translate this into environment + measurements that reference values can say anything about.

I don't know why measured-component is preferable to a cmw. I don't even see a signature, just signers, so you're looking instead at not a named COSE_Sign1 object, but a payload and authority description that have no provable relevance to each other.

Is the idea that the signer of the EAT has somehow been delegated the authority to speak for these signers?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Apparently, the signer field has managed to confuse more than one intelligent person :-)

Laurence has proposed some text in #6 that I have just integrated in #13.

Please, have a look at the PR and see if the additional prose clarifies your understanding of the "signer" idea.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: The way to plug it into CoRIM is to add the CBOR MC to the `$$measurement-values-map-extension`.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Added the "wontfix" label as this issue is going to be worked on in the context of CoRIM.

issues.title: User defined flags
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
It'd be useful to allow some (limited) extensibility to MCs.

One way to do that, while also trying to minimise intrusiveness, is to add an optional "profile-flags" attribute to the MC that EAT profiles can decide to include in the MC and populate with custom values matching their private semantics.

Something like:

```
profile-flags uint64 .bits pflags

pflags = &(
  // ...
)
```

An alternative to this design is to add an extensible socket to the MC.
This would allow open-ended extensibility.
However, it'd also go against the "simple design" principle which is an integral feature of MCs.


See also #7

issues.title: The top-level MC should be a map
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: To allow more flexibility in the assembly (especially with optional fields), the top-level MC should be a map rather than an array.

issues.title: Add JSON examples
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: Currently, the document has CBOR examples only.  We should add some equivalent JSON examples.

issues.title: CDDL sync
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Things to consider:

1. `corim.digest` won't be available in time, and even if it were, since it's CBOR-only, we'd need to add the JSON counterpart...
2. the EAT types (`JC`, and `sw-version-type`) will hopefully become available automatically via the `cddl(1)` tool once 9711 is published.

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body:
Relying on the constantly evolving list of new CDDL features, which are not yet implemented in validation tools or code generators, is obviously risky.

I cannot really give a good recommendation on what to do there because there are also benefits in using these features.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Using [`JC<J,C>`](https://github.com/cbor-wg/cddl/wiki/Useful-CDDL#jcj-c) is okay, I think.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Using [`JC<J,C>`](https://github.com/cbor-wg/cddl/wiki/Useful-CDDL#jcj-c) is okay, I think.

Sure, we are using it.  The problem is that we are currently providing our own [implementation of the EAT CDDL](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-eat-measured-component/blob/main/cddl/minimal-eat.cddlc).

Ideally, we would just use it from cddlc.  Unfortunately, RFC9711 is not yet included in the [cddlc/data](https://github.com/cabo/cddlc/tree/master/data) bag.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: With regard to `corim.digest`, I believe it would be better to drop our reliance on the CoRIM CDDL and provide our own implementation.

issues.title: What if profile is not known?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
> The idea is that the profile of the wrapping EAT determines the
> semantics of all the MCs found within that EAT instance.
> If receivers don't know which EAT profile they are dealing with, I am
not sure how they can successfully interpret the EAT. But assuming they
could, then I'd say: do what your local configuration tells you to do
(i.e., either ignore or reject).
> If receivers know which EAT profile they are dealing with and signers
and flags are not as expected, then reject.

[CW] That all makes sense and maybe could just be stated in the draft. It seems odd that the draft leaves open the possibility of no profile to be present (which is fine) but does not describe how to interpret the fields in that case. Rejection seems fine, i.e., it is an error for a sender to prepare an EAT that features these fields with no profile and receivers should reject EATs created that way.

issues.title: IANA early review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
Amanda:

> _”In Section 8.2, please specify the range the CoAP Content-Format value should be assigned from. See https://www.iana.org/assignments/core-parameters for the registry’s registration procedure table."_

issues.title: Remove `.size 64` constraint from flags
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
A slightly more radical approach to the current extension mechanism is to remove the `.size 64` constraint:

```
extn-type = eat.JC<bytes-b64u, bytes>
```

and allow *any* _profile-defined_ semantics, e.g.:
```
extn-type = bytes .cbor my-extension-map
extn-type = text .json my-extension-map
```

This way, we can have more structured/richer information in addition to the bitmask or the virtually unlimited codepoint space that the current type supports.

Note that, similar to the `signer` claim, this is opaque to the generic EAT processor and would instead be interpreted by the profile-specific processor.

-----

Carsten suggested that an explicit socket may be a better choice over raw bytes in terms of type identification.
However, when embedded in an EAT (which is the case for EAT MCs), the overall type is fully described in the EAT profile.

Since the document also defines the information model, this must be made an explicit requirement for “other”, non-EAT data models.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Not enough traction to justify the change.

issues.title: Support “raw” measurements
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
It is quite common for attestation schemes (e.g., TCG DICE, DMTF SPDM) to allow “raw” measurements alongside digested ones.

This issue tracks the requirements and addition of a “raw” measurement type as an alternative to the existing digested format.

issues.title: Security considerations, motivation and terminology
issues.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
issues.body:
[ For tracking [WGLC comments](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/rats/J0M2e1uicS5MGtG9JV3zssMRVQM/)  ]

## Major

The security considerations are clearly insufficient. As an example, why would security 
considerations of EAT not apply here? What is the desired property that 
this format achieves that CoSWID does not achieve?

## Minor

Introduction is not doing a good job of justifying a draft. Please 
expand to explain why is there a need for a new format.

Properly define information and data model in terminology.

I have submitted PR #43 for a small terminology mismatch.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> The security considerations are clearly insufficient. As an example, why would security considerations of EAT not apply here?

Yes.  We should add references to §9.1, §9.4 and §9.5 of EAT.

> What is the desired property that this format achieves that CoSWID does not achieve?

Clarification: this doesn't appear to be a security consideration, but rather a request to explain why something other than CoSWID is being defined; is it not?

 
> Introduction is not doing a good job of justifying a draft. Please expand to explain why is there a need for a new format.

OK

> Properly define information and data model in terminology.

Not sure.  Table 1 already provides the necessary definitions as part of the information model.  Moving (or copying) them into the terminology section seems wrong (or redundant).

> I have submitted PR [#43](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-eat-measured-component/pull/43) for a small terminology mismatch.

Thank you for that.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: This was addressed in #45 #46 and #49

reviews.author: hannestschofenig
reviews.body: I could not find any problems with the proposed nit-fixes and examples.

comments.body:
doing one sentence per line

```suggestion
A measured component refers to an object within the attester's target environment, whose state can be inspected and digested.
A digest is typically computed through a cryptographic hash function.
Examples of measured components include firmware stored in flash memory, software loaded into memory at start time, data stored in a file system, or values in a CPU register.
```
```suggestion
A measured component refers to an object within the attester's target environment, whose state can be inspected and digested. A digest is typically computed through a cryptographic hash function. Examples of measured components include firmware stored in flash memory, software loaded into memory at start time, data stored in a file system, or values in a CPU register.
```

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: Looks good, Thomas.

```suggestion
This information could offer an attacker valuable insights.
```

pulls.title: add example using file system object as component id
pulls.author: thomas-fossati

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: cc @simonfrost-arm

comments.author: hannestschofenig
comments.body: Because the name is just a string you could put anything in there, even a file path. Is it a problem that there is no semantic associated with the name?

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> Because the name is just a string you could put anything in there, even a file path. Is it a problem that there is no semantic associated with the name?

I consider the free form of the ID as a feature of MC's `component-id`, which allows it to adapt smoothly to different kinds of "measured" objects.

applying some address compression :-)

```suggestion
 - name: Henk Birkholz
   org: Fraunhofer SIT
   email: henk.birkholz@sit.fraunhofer.de
```

re-applying some address compression

```suggestion
 - name: Henk Birkholz
   org: Fraunhofer SIT
   email: henk.birkholz@ietf.contact
```
okay, fine

Query whether we should drop the word 'software' in order to embrace config blobs etc? Ditto below.  
Otherwise, rewording looks good.

```suggestion
| Signers | One or more unique identifiers of entities signing the component that is measured. | OPTIONAL |
```

```suggestion
A signer is an entity that digitally signed the component that is measured.
```

pulls.title: Correct terminology for Component Name and Component Version
pulls.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
pulls.body: "Name" and "Version" is undefined in the draft. I think you mean Component Name and Component Version

pulls.title: Refer to the relevant security considerations from EAT.
pulls.author: thomas-fossati

comments.body:
```suggestion
Please review {{Sections 9.1 (Claim Trustworthiness), 9.4 (Multiple EAT Consumers) and 9.5 (Detached EAT Bundle Digest Security Considerations) of -rats-eat}}; these considerations apply to measured components when used within an EAT. If used used in a different container, similar security considerations must be put in place at the claim container level.
```

Thoughts?

```suggestion
Security considerations {{Sections 9.1 (Claim Trustworthiness), 9.4 (Multiple EAT Consumers) and 9.5 (Detached EAT Bundle Digest Security Considerations) of -rats-eat}} apply to this document as well.
```

when you suggest:
> _"If used in a different container, similar security considerations must be put in place at the claim container level.”_

What kind of container do you have in mind?

Any other signed bag of claims. I know the primary purpose for MC is use in EAT, but maybe someone will want to use it as part of a different data type.

I guess it doesn't even have to be a signed data type, but I hope it's more clear what I mean.
OK, so you are thinking at the information model level rather than the EAT serialisation that is described in the draft.

Right, but even the serialisation can be ~stolen~ imported into some other data model.

Feel free to resolve this if you think this is unlikely to be reused, though!
I agree it’s a valid suggestion.  I was just trying to understand your end goal.

I am thinking of something like:

> _“Note that similar security and privacy considerations may apply when the Measured Component information model is serialised using a different data model to the one specified in this document.”_

WDYT?
See [42732ee](https://github.com/ietf-rats-wg/draft-ietf-rats-eat-measured-component/pull/45/commits/42732ee5ebf525915a5972879467239914b41bbf)
